subject: Re: Need Advice on Unit Testing Pain
msgSnippet: ... I was looking at, IIRC, J2EEUnit which seems to have mocks for the HTTP request and session as part of its framework.  But I didn t get very far with it at
messageBody:
Robert Leftwich wrote:

> I have been using mock objects (in particular EasyMock -
> http://tammofreese.de/easymock/index.html, it's great!) to ease the sort of
> pain you are talking about.
>
> I have found that using mock objects for the servlet specific classes
> enables me to easily test the page content (using XPath expressions on the
> DOM produced by the Java presentation classes) and the navigation, firstly
> by checking the links, etc in the page content and secondly by checking any
> redirection performed in the Java code. I am not doing J2EE (I use
> Enhydra/Barracuda servlets) so I don't know how easy it would be to setup
> the mock objects for that environment but it is extremely simple, using
> EasyMock at least, to setup HttpRequest/Response/Session objects to enable
> this sort of testing using JUnit.

I was looking at, IIRC, J2EEUnit which seems to have mocks for the HTTP
request and session as part of its framework. But I didn't get very far
with it at the time. Easy Mock sounds cool, I'll have to take a look.

Anyone have any experiences with J2EEUnit, or with otherwise simulating
HTTP sessions and responses?

> By way of illustration, I found 5 bugs (admittedly somewhat obscure) on the
> first page I used this technique on, a login page that had been in
> production for some months, purely because it was easy to setup a number of
> different scenarios in the mock objects that the login code used.
>
> [...]
>
> PS The code I am testing is very much as thin as possible, I make heavy use
> of facades to make the ui/web server specific code as simple as I can,
> originally in the hope that it couldn't possible break, so it wouldn't need
> unit testing. However, the recent releases I have made have had problems
> found by QA in that thin layer (and only in that layer) that wasn't being
> unit tested, hence the use of mock objects.

These are the kinds of things that some of our developers worry about.
We'd hate to have QA or even the end users find these, mostly because
any bugs found after a release cause us to back up and fix things,
rather than move forward onto new features.

Thanks for the comments,
-Paul Hodgetts
